title: Why Poland's punchy politics hasn't hit its ebullient economy - yet
text:
“Everybody is always looking at the political risks,” says Dorota Latkowska of real estate fund manager Reino Partners. “But the political issues are much the same across Europe. When investors see there is still growth in the business, then the political risk becomes the second or third [issue].”

It’s true that the economic story has been pretty impressive. The year-on-year growth rate has been above 4 per cent since the start of 2017.

You can feel it on the streets of central Warsaw, where shiny glass towers are springing from the derelict blocks of the communist period. One of them is aspiring to become the tallest skyscraper in Europe, topping out one metre higher than London’s Shard.

Buildings are shooting up in formerly derelict areas of Poland's capital Warsaw. Bloomberg

“The Polish economy is changing so quickly, it’s hard to get people to realise what’s happening,” says Tadeusz Koscinski, the England-born deputy finance minister.

EU money has poured in, driving infrastructure and social development, to the tune of €104.8 billion ($169 billion) between 2014 and 2020. That is now drying up – the price of success, since Poland is generally considered a developed country – but foreign investors have been stepping in. The flow of foreign capital jumped 25 per cent in 2018 (admittedly off a pretty poor 2017).

In the past two or three years, Warsaw has sought to claim the mantle of central Europe’s main hub, and banks have noticed. JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs, Standard Chartered and Credit Suisse have opened decent-sized offices. More may follow, as the banks tend to move in a pack– “it’s a herd mentality”, says Mike Kennedy, founder of Talent Alpha and a former Goldmans exec in Warsaw.

The capital’s 1.7 million population turns out to be a reservoir of well-educated, English-speaking youth, where wages, although growing, are still relatively cheap. The real estate is also good value.

Advertisement

“If I’m looking at a 17,000 sq m negotiation, it’ll be one-third the cost of ‘old Europe’,” says Jedrzej Iwaszkiewicz, from the Heart Corporate Centre for Digital Ventures.

Warsaw mayor Rafat Trzaskowski says many British companies in particular are “knocking on our doors and saying 'can we do business here in Poland?'”. Chartered accountants, banks – “this is not just back office, they want to have regional headquarters here”.

Foreigners still welcome?

But it’s not all rosy. PwC’s chief economic adviser in Poland, Witold Orlowski, says Poland is at a crossroads.

He reckons investment is slowing down, and the nationalistic approach of the PiS isn’t helping. The ruling party is responsible with the budget, he says, but are talking a big game about a state-led approach to future infrastructure investment, led by public-sector companies and excluding foreign participation.

This "re-Polonisation", as its known, would be disappointing news for the big Australian superannuation funds and Macquarie, who would doubtless like to replicate investments such as that at Gdansk Port.

Macquarie, AustralianSuper, MTAA Super and Statewide Super sold the asset in June for more than $1.8 billion to a consortium including IFM Investors and also the state-owned Polish Development Fund.

Advertisement

The jewel in the infrastructure development crown is the proposed €17 billion Solidarity Transport Hub Poland, an airport 37 kilometres from Warsaw plus 1600 kilometres of new railway linking it to all parts of the country.

The state is developing it at the moment, and the Hub’s acting president Piotr Malepszak says it's still too early to say if private investors will be invited in. If they were, it would be for the €7 billion airport component.

Before, anyone who wanted to come and invest was welcome. Now, we simply tell people what we want. — Warsaw mayor Rafat Trzaskowski

Back in Warsaw, there’s a second metro line under construction, funded by the EU. As the EU funds evaporate, though “we cannot build such infrastructure projects on our own”, says mayor Trzaskowski.

Orlowski, though, isn’t sure how far the government will go.

“If you listen to Polish state TV you will hear so many bad things about foreign investment. But if you listen to the Prime Minister talking to foreign investors in English, you’ll hear about how Poland wants to welcome them,” he says.

Koscinski, the deputy finance minister, says his government wants foreign investors, but not at any price.

“We’re not looking for investors who will open a factory and create 1000 jobs – we have a very low unemployment rate. We’re looking for investors to work with universities to do their R &D here in Poland, creating good quality jobs, build their supply chains here, and build production for exports.”

Advertisement

Warsaw mayor Trzaskowski agrees: “Before, anyone who wanted to come and invest was welcome. Now, we simply tell people what we want. And they know it, they adapt to it. We don’t just want huge commercial centres, we want multi-function and we want our heritage to be protected.”

Prime Minister Mateusz Moriawecki, an economist by training, has kept up the populist rhetoric of his predecessor, but tempered its edges.

He’ll publicly push “culture wars” buttons – particularly on gay issues – when it suits him, but leaves the heavy lifting on that to the party’s hardline leader, Jaroslaw Kaczynski.

Jaroslaw Kaczynski, chairman of the Law & Justice party (PiS), arrives at an election rally. Bloomberg

The government’s main stated priority during the election campaign hasn’t been the longstanding push against Western European liberalism; rather, they’ve focused on a plan to “rebalance the social model”, by which they mean direct more public spending to their rural political base.

Economic pressures

This program includes more social spending, a higher minimum wage, and a lower retirement age. That may put pressure on a labour market already as tight as they come: unemployment is just 3.8 per cent, and the unskilled end of the market depends on heavy borrowing of labour from neighbouring Ukraine.

Wages are still relatively low, but there’s the possibility inflation could break out of its holding pattern. It’s already at 3 per cent. That would come just as a slowdown in Poland’s most important export market, Germany, takes hold.

Advertisement

Orlowski’s tipping growth of 2.6 per cent in 2020, down from 4 per cent this year, while inflation will spike to 4.6 per cent, up from 2.5 per cent this year.

This would make life interesting from Poland’s central bank, which has kept the benchmark interest rate steady at 1.5 per cent. The bank's official view is that inflation will spike briefly before settling, and that the PiS plan to boost the minimum wage won’t fuel price growth.

There's some context for this remarkably sanguine view: most of the central bank’s board were appointed by the PiS, and the governor is a friend of party leader Kaczynski.

Still, nothing to see here apparently. Poland last year made the top 40 chart of Transparency International’s corruption perception index, outperforming Spain and Italy. And it’s also in the top 30 of the World Bank’s ease of doing business index.

The CEO of Poland’s national airline LOT, Rafal Milczarski, tells journalists the country has made impressive strides in cutting red tape and stamping out corruption, including under the business-friendly PiS

“I am bewildered by the success of the current government,” he says. “Today the Polish economy is a completely different bowl of cereal.”

So if you’re an investor, bon appetit. But if you’re a liberal voter or politician, this weekend you'll likely be crying into your cornflakes.

The writer travelled to Warsaw as a guest of Poland Today magazine.
description: The anti-liberal ruling party PiS is set for fresh election glory. It's wary of foreign capital but isn't yet slamming the door on Europe's economic dynamo.
